div.p:
IV. 62 55
entirely the excessive longing and
dreaming about roasted ribs of
fat oxen and by bowls of cool
thick milk gurgling forth from
the greasy big bellied calabashes
and I could understand the
thankfulness of poor Bakwain
women (in anthe interesting condition)
to Mrs L.Livingstone for a little milk or meat -

Had there been no other adverse
influences at work the general
uncertainty though ^ not absolute want
of food - and the necessity for
frequent absence - for ^ the purpose of either hunting
or collecting roots and fruits, proved
a serious barrier to progress in
educationknowledge, our own education
was carried on at the comfortable
breakfast and dinner tables and
by the cosy fire, as well as in the
church and school room - ^ Few English
would be decorous
at Church on over
empty stomachs
noany more thenan
^ they are on over full
ones -
Ragged schools would have been
a failures had the teachers not
wisely provided food for the
body as well as food for the
mind - And not only must we shewshow
a friendly interest in their bodily
comforts as a christian duty, but
we can no more hope for healthy
feelings among the poor either
at home or abroad without
feeding ^ them into them than we can
hope to see an ordinary working
bee fed into a queen mother
by the ordinary food of the hive

63 56
Sending the gospel to the heathen
must if this reasoning view be
correct, include much more than
the usually picture of a missionary
implies; ^ viz.videlicet a man going about with a
bible under his arm - The promotion
Queries
Reflections
for the
last Chapter
of the work of ofcommerce ought to be specially
attended to as this more speedily
than aught else demolishes that
feeling of isolation which heathenism
engenders, and makes the natives
of the worldtribes feel themselves
mutually dependant ^ on and mutually
beneficial to each other - Those
laws which ^ still prevent the freest
commercial ^ intercourse intercourse among
the civilized, seem to be nothing
else but the remains of our own
heathenism - My own experience
makes me intensely desirous
to promote the preparation of the
raw materials of European
manufactures in Africa for
by that means we willshall
not only put a stop to the slave
trade but introduce the negro
family into the body corporate
of nations no one ^ member portion
of which can suffering without
the others suffering with it - Success
in this in both Eastern and
Western Africa would lead in
the course of time to a much
larger diffusion of the blessings
civilization & Christianity
64 57
than efforts more purely spiritual
and educational - These however
if would be extremely desirable
to carry on at the same time
The English character should never
be exhibited except in connection
with Christianity -

Another adverse influence
with which the mission had to
contend was the vicinity of the
Boers of the Cashan mountains
otherwise named "Magaliesberg" -
These are not to be confounded
with the Cape Colonists who sometimes
pass by the name - The word simply
means "farmers" and is not
synonymous with our word
Boor, Indeed takingto them generally
there term is inappropriate for
they are a sober, religious, industrious
and most hospitable ^ body of peasantry -
Those who however have fled
from English law on various
pretexts, and have been joined
by English deserters and every
other variety of bad character in
their distant localities are un-
-fortunately of ^ a very different peoplestamp
The great objection many of them
had ^ and do still have to English law wasis that it makes
no distinction between black &
white - , They felt aggrieved by their
supposed losses in the emancipation
of their Hottentot slaves, and
65 58
determined to erect themselves into
a republic in which they might
pursue without molestation the
"proper treatment of the blacks - "
without It is almost needless to
add that the "proper system" has
always contained ^ in it the essential
element of slavery viz.videlicet compulsory
unpaid labour without payment -
One section of this body under
Mr Hendrick Potgeiter came in
as far as the Cashan mountains
whence a Caffre chief named
Mosilikatze had been expelled
by the well known ^ Caffre Dingaan, and
a glad welcome was given them
by the Bechuana tribes who had just
escaped the hard sway of that cruel
chieftain - They came with the
prestige of white men and deliverers,
but the Bechuanas soon found
that as they express it, "that Mosilikatze
was cruel to his enemies butand kind to those
he conquered, but the Boers destroy
their enemies and make slaves
of their friends" - The tribes who still
retain the semblance of independence
are forced to performed all the labour
21 of the fields - as [manuring the land,
weeding, reaping, building - making
dams, and canals and at the
same time to support themselves -
I have myself been an eyewitness
of Boers coming to a village according
66 59
to their usual custom and demanding
twenty or thirty women to weed gardens,
and have seen theose women proceed
to the scene of unrequited toil carrying
their ^ own food on their heads - and
their children on their backs and
instruments of labour on their shoulders
and so far from any wish to conceal
the meanessmeanness of employing unpaid
labour ^ Every one from Mr Potgeiter and
Mr Gert Kruger ^ the commandants downwards they
lauded theirhis own humanity &
justice in making such a fine
equitable ^ regulation - ^ "We make "the people work for
us in consideration of allowing
them to live in our country" I
can appeal to the Commandant
Kruieger if the foregoing is not a
fair and impartial statement
of his own and ^ his people's views -
I am sensible of no mental bias
towards or against these boersBoers
and during the manyseveral journiesjourneys
I made to the poor enslaved tribes
never avoided the whites but
tried to cure & to administer remedies to the
sick without money and without
price - It is due to them to state that
I was invariably treated by them
with respect, but it is most
unfortunate that they should have
been left by their own church for
so many years to deteriorate
and become soas much degraded
as the blacks whom the unfortunate
prejudice against colour leads them to
detest

67 60
This new species of slavery they have
adopted serves to supply the lack of
field labour only - The demand
for domestic servants must be met
by forays on tribes which have
good supplies of cattle - The Portuguese
can quote instances in which
blacks become so degraded by love
of strong drinks as actually to
sell themselves - but never in
anyoneany one case within the memory
of man has a Bechuana chief
sold his people or a Bechuana
man his child - Hence the necessity
for a foray to seize children and
those individuals Boers who would
not engage in it for the sake of
slaves seldom can resist the
twofold plea of a well told story of an
intended ^ uprising of the devoted
tribe, and handsome pay in
the division of the captured cattle -
besides - It is difficult for a person in
a civilised country to concieveconceive
that if any body of men possessing
the common attributes of
humanity, (and these boersBoers are
by no means destitute of the
finer feelings of our nature), with
one accord ^ would setting out & after
loading their own wives and
children with kisses, & ^ and proceeding
to shoot down in cold blood
men of a different colour, it is
true,
68 61
but possessed of domestic feelings
and longings equal to their own - I It
was long before I could give
credit to the tales of bloodshed
told meby native witnesses, and had
I found no other testimony I should
probably ^ have continued to this day
sceptical as to their authenticity -
but when I found these Boers
themselves; some bewailing and
denouncing; others glorying in
the ^ bloody scenes in which they had
been themselves the actors I was
compelled to admit the validity
of the testimony and try to
account for the ^ cruel anomaly -
They are all traditionally religious
having tracing their descent to
some of the best men the world
ever saw - Hence they claim to
themselves the title of "Christians" &
all the coloured race are "black
property" "or creatures" - They being
the chosen people of God
the heathen are given to them
for an inheritance, and they
as & were the Jews, are the rod
of Divine vengeance on the
Heathen - Living in the midst of
a much larger population than
themselves and at fountains
removed at distances of many
miles from each other they
feel somewhat in the same position
as do that the Americans in the Southern states
69 62
and when they recievereceive reports from
the disaffected or envious ^ natives against
any tribe it the case assumes all the
proportions of regular insurrection
Severe measures then appear
to the most mildly disposed among
them as imperatively called for -
And however bloody the massacre
that follows no qualms of
conscience followensue It was iswas a dire
necessity for the sake of peace
Indeed the late Mr Hendrick Potgeiter
most devoutly believed himself to be the great
peace maker of the country -

But how is it the natives
being so vastly superior in numbers
to the Boers do not rise and
annihilate them? The people
among whom they live are Bechuanas
not Caffres, though no one would
ever learn that distinction from
a Boer, and history does not
contain one single instance
in which even the Bechuanas
even who possess firearms have
attacked either the Boers or English
If there is such an instance
I am certain it is not generally
known either beyond or in the
Cape Colony - They have defended
themselves when attacked as in
the cases of the ambush of Sechele
but never have engaged in
offensive war with Europeans -
nor have they ever been guilty of
70 63
We have a very different tale to tell
of the Caffres and the difference
has always been so patent to these
border boersBoers that ever since
* Union Service
Gazette so styles them "those magnificent savages" * obtained
possession of firearms not
one of them ever attempted to
settle in Caffreland or even
face them as an enemy in the
field - The Boers have generally
manifested a marked antipathy
to anything but "long shot" warfare
and sidling away in their
emiggrations towards the more
effeminate Bechuanas, left
their quarrels with the caffres
to be settled by the English
and the wars to be paid for
by English gold -

The Bakwains at Kolobeng
had the spectacle of various
tribes enslaved before their eyes
the Bakatla, the Batlokua, the
Bahukeng, the Bamosetla
Two other tribes of Bakwain were
all groaning under the oppression
of unrequiting labour - This would
not have been felt such an evil,
but the young men of those tribes
anxious to obtain cattle - the only
means of rising to respectability
onamong their own people were in
the habit of sallying forth like our
Irish and Highland shearers to
71 64
procure work in the Cape Colony -
There labouring three or four years
in building stone-dykes and dams
for the Dutch Farmers, they were
well content if at the end of that
time they could return at the end of
that time with threeas many cows,
After presenting one to their chief - they
ranked as respectable men ^ in the tribe ever
afterwards - These volunteers were
highly esteemed among the Dutch under
the name Mantatees - They were paid
at the rate of one shilling a day and
a large loaf of bread between
six of them - Numbers of them who
had seen me about 1200 miles
inland from the Cape recognized
me with ^ the loud laughter of joy
when I was passing them at their
work in the RoggefeltRoggevelt & BokkefeltBokkevelt
within a few days of Cape town
I wshould apbe borne out in my
statement ^ as literally true by elders in
the Dutch Church to whom they
were working, that the system
was thoroughly satisfactory to both
parties, and I cannot believe
that there as a Boer ^ either in the Cashan
or Magaliesberg ^ country who would deny that a
law was made to deprive these
labourers of their hardly earned
cattle for the very cogent reason
that "if they wanted to work let
them work for us their masters" -
I can never cease to be most
72 65
unfeignedly thankful that I was
not born in a land of slaves
No one can understand the effect of
the unutterable meanessmeanness of the slave
system on the minds of those who,
but for the strange obliquity which
prevents them from feeling the
degradation of not being gentleman
enough to pay for services
rendered, would be equal in
virtue to ourselves - Repudiation
becomes as natural to them as
"paying one's way" is to the rest of
mankind -

Whenever a missionary lives
traders are sure to come - They are
mutually dependant and each
aids in the work of the other
but all experience shewsshows that the
two employments cannot be
combined in the same person -
Such a combination would not be
morally wrong for nothing would
be more fair ^ and apostolical too than that the man
who devotes his life to the welfare of
a people should desire the temporal
advantages from upright tradingcommerce
which traders who aim exclusively
at their own enrichment modestly
imagine ought to be left to them -
But though it would be right for
missionaries to trade the present
system renders it inexpedient
to spend theany time in so doing - No one
73 66
with whom I ever came in contact
traded, and while the traders whom
theywe introduced into the country
waxed rich the missionaries
have invariably remained poor
and died so - The Jesuits were
wiser in their generation than we -
Theirs were large influential
communities proceeding on
the system of turning the
abilities of every brother into
that channel in which he was
most likely to excel - One fond of
Naturally history was allowed
to pursue his bent - - Another offond
of literature found leizureleisure to pursue
his studies, and he who ofwas
great in barter was sent in
searches of ivory and gold dust
; so that while in the course of
performing the religious acts
of his mission to distant tribes
he found the means of
aiding effectually the bretherenbrethren
whom he had left at home -
We protestants with the comfortable
conviction of superiority have
sendt out agents missionaries onwith
a bare subsistence only, and are
unsparing in our laudations
of those ^ some whom our niggardliness
made to live as did the ^ returning Prodigal
son in the middle of his career
for not being worldy minded
74 67
which is about as wise as praising
an ugly woman for not being
vain of her beauty -

English traders sold those articles
which the Boers most dread - vizvidelicet
arms and ammunition - And
when the number of guns amounted
to five so much alarm was
excited among our neighbours
that an expedition of several
hundred Boers was seriously
planned to come and deprive
the Bakwains of their guns -
Knowing that the latter would
rather have fled to the Kalahari
Desert than deliver up their
weapons and become slaves
I proceeded to the Commandant
Mr Gert Krieger and representing
the evils which any such
expedition would do prevailed
upon him to defer it - But
that point being granted the Boer
wished to gain another which
was that I should beact as a spy over
the Bakwains - I explained the
impossibility of my complying
with his wish even though
my principles as an Englishman
were not in the way, by referring
to an instance in which
Sechele had gone with his
whole force to punish an
underchief without my knowledge
75 68
Kāke an underchief rebelled and
was led on in his rebellion by
ahis fathers in law who had
QyQuery explain been regicide in the case of
Sechele's father - Several of
those who remained faithful
were maltreated by KakeKāke
while passing to the Desert in
search of skins - We had just
come to live with the Bakwains
when this happened and Sechele
consulted me - I advised mild
measures but his messengers
were taunted with the words - "He
only pretends to wish to follow
the advice of the teacher - he isSechele
is a coward - let him come"
The next time the offence was
repeated Sechele told me he
was going to hunt elephants
and as I knew the system
of espionage which prevails
among all the tribes I never
made any enquiries on any
subject that would convey
the opinion that I distrusted
them - I gave credit to his
statement - He asked the loan
of a black metal pot to cook
with as theirs of pottery are
brittle, I gave it and a handful
of salt and desired him to
send back two tidtbits - the proboscis
and fore foot of the Elephant
76 69
and knew nothing more until
we saw the Bakwains carrying
home their wounded, and heard
some of the women uttering the
loud wail of sorrow for the
dead and others pealing forth
the clear scream of victory -
It was clear that they had
25 attacked and driven away [the
rebel - Mentioning this to the
Commandant in proof of
the impossibility of granting
his request, I had soon an
example of how quickly a story
can grow among idle people
Knowing that I used a sextant
The five guns were within one
month magnified multiplied into into five
a tale of ^ five hundred, and the cooking pot
where? now in a museum at Cape town was
magnified into a cannon -
"I had myself confessed to the
loan" - Where the five hundred
guns came ^ from it was easy to
divine, for knowing that
I used a sextant my connection
with Government was a
thing of course - And as I must
know all Her Majesty's councisels
I was questioned on the
subject of the ^ indistinct rumours
which had reached them of Lord
Rosse's telescope - "What right has
your GovtGovernment to get up that large
glass at the Cape to look after us behind the Cashan"
77 70
mountains" - ? Many of them
visited us afterwards some for
medical advice and others to
trade in those very articles which
their own laws and policy
forbid - When I happened to
light stumble upon one of the
latter in the town with his
muskets & powder displayed
he would begin an apology
on the ground that he was a
poor man &c which I always
cut short by frankly saying
I had nothing to do with either
the Boers or their laws - Many
attempts were made during
these visits to elicit the truth
about the guns & cannon - And
ignorant of the system of
espionage which prevails
expected eager enquiries were
made among those who could
jabber a little Dutch - It is
noticeable that the system of
espionage is as well developed
among the savage tribes as
in Austria or Russia - It is
a proof of barbarism - Every
man in a tribe feels himself
bound to tell the chief every thing
that comes to his knowledge
and when questioned either give
answers which exhibit the
utmost stupidity or such as he
knows will be agreeable to
78 71
to his chief - I believe that in this
way have arisen tales of inability
to count ten or even smaller
numbers - As Mr BurchelBurchell was
led to believe this of the Bechuanas
about the very at a time when Sechele's father
counted out one thousand head
of cattle as a beginning of the
stock of his young son - In the
present case Sechele knowing
every question put to his people
asked me how they ought to
answer - My reply was "tell
the truth" Every one ^ then declared
that they had no cannon
existed there and our friends judging the
answer by what they themselves
would have in the circumstances
have said, were confirmed in
the opinion that the Bakwains
actually possessed artillery - This
was so far beneficial as
fear prevented any foray
in our direction for eight
years - During that time no
winter passed without one
or two tribes being plundered
of both cattle and children
The plan pursued is the following
One or two friendly tribes
are forced to accompany them
a party of mounted boersBoers and
these expeditions can be
got up only in the winter when
horses can be used -
79 72
and when they reach the tribe to be
attacked the friendly natives are
ranged in front to form as they
say a shield - The boersBoers then
cooly fire over their heads till
the devoted people flee and
leave cattle wives and children
to the captors - This was done in
nine cases during my residence
in the Interior and on no
occasion was a drop of Boer's
blood shed - Well, news of
these deeds spread quickly among
the Bakwains and letters were
repeatedly sent to Sechele ordering
to come and surrender himself
as their vassal - and stop English
traders from coming into the
country with firearms for sale
But the discovery of Lake
Ngami hereafter to be described
made the traders come in fivefold
greater numbers and Sechele replied
"I was made an independent
chief ^ ^ & placed here by God and not by you
I was never conquered by
Mosilikatze as those tribes whom
you rule over - And the English
are my friends and I gaveget me
everything I wish from them -
I cannot hinder them from
going where they like" Those who
are old enough to remember
the threatened invasion of our
own island many understand
80 73
the effect which the constant danger
of a Boerish invasion had on
the minds of the Bakwains, but
no others can appreciate concieveconceive
how worrying were the messages
and threats from the endless
self constituted authorities of the
Magaliesberg burghers - and
when that was combined
with the death produced by the
drought, we could not wonder
over though felt sorry for
their indisposition to recievereceive
instruction -

The myth of the black pot assumed
serious proportions - I attempted
to benefit the tribes among the Boers
of Magaliesberg by placing native
teachers at different points - "You
must teach the blacks" said Mr
Hendrick Potgeiter the thoog command-
ant - "that they are not equal
to us" - Other Boers said I "might
as well teach the Baboons on
the rocks as the Africans" but
declined to declined the test which
I proposed as to whether they
or my attendants could read
best - Two clergymen came on
a baptising tour so supposing
these good men would assist
me in overcoming the repugnance
of their flock to the blacks being
instructed I called on them -
but my visit ended in a
81 74
QyQuery "rusé" by the Boerish commandant
whereby I was led by professions
of the greatest friendship to
retire to Kolonbeng and a letter
passed me by an other way
to the other missionaries in
the South demanding my
instant recalrecall "for lending a
cannon to their enemies" And the
Colonial Government was
gravely informed by my clerical
friends that the story was
true - and I came to be looked
upon as a most suspicious
character

These notices of the Boers are
not intended to produce a sneer
at their ignorance but to excite
the compassion of their friends
They are perpetually talking about
their laws but practically theirs
is only the law of the strongest
The Bakwains could never
understand the changes which
took places in their commandants
"Why one can never know
who is the chief among the
Boers - They ^ have this king and are like the Bushmen
and must be the Bushmen
of the English" The idea that
every tribe of men could be so
senseless as not to have a
hereditary chief was so absurd
to those natives that in order
82 75
not to appear equally stupid I was
obliged to tell that we were so
anxious to preserve the royal
blood we had made a little girl
our chief - This seemed to them
a most convincing proof of our
sound sense - We shall yet see
the confidence my account of
our qQueen inspired farther on -

The Boers at last encouraged
by the accession of Mr Pretorius
determined at last to put a
stop to English traders going past
Kolobeng by dispersing the
tribe of Bakwains and
expelling all missionaries - Sir
George Cathcart proclaimed
their independence - probably the
best thing that could have been
done in the circumstances of
the case - The policy, however
of H. M.Her Majesty's commissioner Owen
acting byunder the authority of that
noble hearted man was very
questionable - These commissioners
anxious to conciliate the Dutch
Colonists often make monstrous
mistakes by taking forming
an opinion of their character
through English Colonial channels
A late Governor for instance
had the idea that the Dutch farmers
of the Cape ^ are ferociously blood thirsty
and when sorely pressed in Caffre war
83 76
actually called upon them to "exterminate
the Caffres in their own way - Not
a man responded to the Proclamation
In point of humanity the English
border A treaty was entered
into by our commissioner andwith
these Boers and articles for
the free passage of Englishmen
to the country beyond and
also foranother that no slavery should
be allowed in the independantindependent
territory were duly inserted as
expressive of the views of H. M.Her Majesty's
Government at home - // What
about the missionaries enquired
the Boers - "You may do as
you please with them", is the
reported answer - It is difficult
to believe that any Englishman
in that responsible position
could so far forget himself
and though the sentence uttered
perhaps in joke led immediately
to the destruction of three mission
stations, it is probable that
designing men may have
circulated and caused the
the general belief as to its accuracy,
it is impossible to avoid
a lingering suspicion seeing
this gentleman had been witness
of a Governor tearing a treaty
containing the QueensQueen's scope
manual & in the presence
of thousands of Caffres scatter
84 77
the fragments to the winds - The
Boers 400 in number were
sent by the late Mr Pretorius to
attack the Bakwains in 1852
and boasting that the English
had given up all the blacks
into their power and had agreed
to aid them in their subjugation
by preventing all supplied &
ammunition from coming
into the Bechuana country
assaulted the Bakwains and
besides killing a considerable
number carried off two hundred
of our school children into slavery
The natives under Sechele defended
themselves till the approach of
night obligedenabled them to flee to the mountains
and having in that defence
killed a number of the Boersenemy &c -
the very first ever slain in the
country I recievedreceived the credit of
having taught my tribe to kill
Boers! My house which had
stood perfectly secure for years
in the protection of the natives
was plundered in revenge - English
gentlemen who had come in the
footsteps of Mr Cumming to hunt
in the country beyond had also
deposited large quantities of
stores for the return journeys
and upwards of 80 head of cattle
as relays were robbed of all, and
85 78
when they came to Kolobeng found
the skeletons of the guardians strewedstrewn
all over the place - The Books
of a good library - my solace in
our solitude were not taken
away but handfuls of the leaves
torn out and both scattered
over the place - My stock of
medicines were smashed butand
all over our furniture and clothing
carried off and sold at public
auction to pay the expenses of
the foray - I do not mention
these things by way of making
a pitiful wail over my losses
to excite commiseration for
though I do feel sorry for the
loss of lexicons and dictionaries &c which had
been the companions of my boyhood
yet after all the plundering only
set me entirely free for my
expedition in the North - and I have
never since had a momentsmoment's
concern for anything I left behind
The Boers would shut up the
Interior because on consulting the
ancient map in their old bibles they
see that Canaan & Cashan are
not far apart - They being God's
own people can therefore claim
right up to Jerusalem - and keep
out all intruders - I resolved to
open upthe country country and we
shall see who has been most
successful in resolution - I or they

The following memorandums are appended
Having married Mary the eldest
daughter of Revd Robert Moffat
in the hope that of Kuruman in ^ January 1845 a short sketch
of African Housekeeping may
perhaps prove interesting to the Reader - The entire absence
of shops leads us to make everything
we need from the raw materials
You want bricks to build a house and
must forthwith proceed to the field
cut down a tree - and saw thatit into planks
to make the brick moulds - The materials
for doors and windows too are
standing in the forest, and if you
want to be respected by the natives a
a decent house of decent dimensions
costing an immense amount of
manual labour must be built - The
people cannot assist you much for
though most willing to labour for
wages the Bechuanas have a curious
inability to make or put things square
In our the case of three large houses, every
brick and stick had to be put rightsquare by
my own right hands ⎡Having seen that
got the meal is ground and erected an
oven the wife is ready proceeds to make it into
bread - An extemporaneouse oven is
